data.Explanation(Korean): 어느 분야에서 최고일 정도로 대단하다, 웹소설 '나 혼자만 레벨업'에서 유래된 표현
data.Example sentence(Korean): 저 친구의 인맥은 거의 국가권력급이다.
data.Background(Korean): 일본 만화 '한마 바키'에서 처음 등장한 표현으로, 한 사람의 전투력이 국가 수준에 버금간다는 의미로 사용되었고, 이후 한국 웹툰 '나 혼자만 레벨업'에서 일부 헌터를 지칭하는 데 쓰이며 인지도를 넓혔고, 방송인 랄로의 사용을 계기로 밈처럼 확산
data.Background(English): The phrase first appeared in the Japanese manga 'Baki the Grappler', where it was used to mean that a person's combat power is comparable to that of a nation. Later, it was used in the Korean webtoon 'Solo Leveling' to refer to certain hunters, which increased its recognition. The phrase spread like a meme after being used by the broadcaster Ralro.
data.combined_text: 국가권력급 Powerful as a national institution 저 친구의 인맥은 거의 국가권력급이다.

data.Background(English): This phrase originated from 'Bakuryu', a character in the Japanese manga 'Makai Taisen', and became popular due to the nickname of a Twitter user. It is used to express strong admiration or impression.

data.Explanation(English): No way out / caught in a dilemma

data.Background(English): The term '박제' originates from the practice of managing schedules and important appointments by recording them in a smartphone calendar app, promising not to forget them. It also refers to the act of storing important information. In this context, '박제' is used to describe these behaviors.
data.combined_text:
캘박 “He keeps spamming emojis and yelling in chat.”
“Classic jaemini behavior…” 나 다음주 수요일 약속있어서 캘박해놨음.

data.Example sentence(Korean): 걔가 맨날 내 탓만 하더니 결국 나만 미안하게 만듦. 완전 가스라이팅 아님?
data.Background(Korean): 1938년 연극 'Gas Light'에서 유래한 심리학 개념으로, 상대의 현실 인식을 교묘히 왜곡해 지배하려는 행위를 지칭하며 2010년대 이후 SNS와 대중문화에서 일상어로 확장됨.
data.Background(English): This is a psychological concept derived from the 1938 play 'Gas Light', referring to the act of subtly distorting another's perception of reality in an attempt to dominate them. Since the 2010s, it has expanded into everyday language through social media and popular culture.
data.combined_text: 가스라이팅 Gaslighting 걔가 맨날 내 탓만 하더니 결국 나만 미안하게 만듦. 완전 가스라이팅 아님?

data.Explanation(English): Feeling of deprivation caused by sudden wealth gaps
data.Explanation(Korean): 갑작스런 자산격차로 인해 상대적 박탈감을 느끼는 상황
data.Example sentence(Korean): 비트코인 올랐던데… 나만 벼락거지 됐네.
data.Background(Korean): 갑자기 큰 돈을 번 '벼락부자'의 반대 의미로 쓰이며, 2020년대 초반 부동산, 주식 등 자산 시장이 급등하던 시기에 재산이 늘지 않아 상대적으로 가난해진 사람을 자조적으로 이르는 말.
data.Background(English): This term is used in contrast to 'nouveau riche,' which refers to someone who suddenly made a lot of money. It was coined in the early 2020s when the real estate and stock markets were booming, and it sarcastically refers to people who became relatively poorer because their wealth did not increase.
data.combined_text: 벼락거지 Feeling of deprivation caused by sudden wealth gaps 비트코인 올랐던데… 나만 벼락거지 됐네.

data.Explanation(Korean):

감정은 다 썼는데 살갑게는 굴어야 할 때의 줄임말.

data.Explanation(English): I have a lot to say, but I won't
data.Example sentence(Korean): 그 사건에 대해선 할많하않이라 더 이상 말하지 않을게.
data.Background(Korean): 하고 싶은 말은 많지만 굳이 말하지 않겠다는 감정을 표현하는 신조어로, 주로 분노·불쾌·어이없음 등의 부정적인 상황에서 대화를 피하거나 감정을 간결히 드러낼 때 사용
data.Background(English): The text is a new slang term that expresses the feeling of having a lot to say but choosing not to. It is mainly used to avoid conversation or to succinctly express emotions in negative situations such as anger, discomfort, or disbelief.

data.Explanation(English): Deep diving into what you love
data.Example sentence(Korean): 좋아하는 배우 덕질을 하면서 행복한 시간을 보냈다.
data.Background(Korean): 일본어 '오타쿠'라는 단어가 '오덕후', '덕'으로 줄여진 말에, 무언가에 몰두하는 행동을 뜻하는 ‘질(짓)’을 붙여 만든 말로, 2000년대 초 팬들이 스스로 창작하고 공유하며 즐기는, 자율적이고 창조적인 팬덤 기반의 하위문화와 함께 퍼지며 누군가나 무언가를 깊게 좋아하고 파고드는 행위를 뜻하는 신조어로 사용
data.Background(English): The term 'Otaku' in Japanese has been shortened to 'Odeokhu' or 'Deok' in Korean, and the word 'Jil (Jit)', which means an act of immersing oneself in something, is added to it. This term was created in the early 2000s and spread along with a subculture based on fandom where fans autonomously create, share, and enjoy. It is a neologism used to describe the act of deeply liking and delving into someone or something.
data.combined_text: 덕질 Deep diving into what you love 좋아하는 배우 덕질을 하면서 행복한 시간을 보냈다.

data.Explanation(English): Otaku / super fan of a field

data.Background(English): The term 'Otaku (おたく)' originated from Japanese and has been used in Korea since the 2000s as a slang term to humorously refer to someone who is deeply obsessed with something.
data.combined_text: 덕후 Otaku / super fan of a field 그 친구는 영화 덕후라서 관련 지식이 엄청나다.

data.Example sentence(Korean): 피자엔 콜라가 국룰이지, 안 그래?
data.Background(Korean): 워크래프트 3 유즈맵 ‘파이트 오브 캐릭터즈’에서 유저들이 정한 게임 내 규칙을 뜻하는 말로 시작되었으나, 초기엔 잘 정착되지 않았고, 이후 FPS 게임 ‘아바온라인’에서 유저들이 만든 ‘칼전 국룰’, ‘스나 국룰’ 등의 암묵적 룰이 유행하면서 본격적으로 쓰이기 시작했습니다. 2017년에는 트위치 스트리머들이 ‘경매 디펜스’라는 스타 유즈맵에서 '첫 경매는 1원이 국룰'이라며 장난처럼 사용한 것이 화제가 되며, 게임뿐 아니라 일상 속 유머성 불문율이나 관행을 가리키는 유행어로 확산
data.Background(English): The term originated from the user-defined rules in the Warcraft 3 custom map 'Fight of Characters', but it did not initially take root. Later, it began to be widely used with the popularity of implicit rules created by users in the FPS game 'A.V.A Online', such as 'Knife Fight Rule' and 'Sniper Rule'. In 2017, Twitch streamers jokingly used the phrase 'the first auction is 1 won by default' in a StarCraft custom map called 'Auction Defense', which became a hot topic. Since then, the term has spread as a buzzword not only in games but also in everyday life, referring to humorous unwritten rules or customs.
data.combined_text: 국룰 Just like everyone else does 피자엔 콜라가 국룰이지, 안 그래?

data.Example sentence(Korean): 회사에서 월루하면서 시간을 보내고 있다.
data.Background(Korean): 프랑스 소설가 모리스 르블랑(Maurice Leblanc)의 작품 속 전설적인 도둑인 ‘아르센 뤼팽(Arsène Lupin)’의 이름과 ‘월급’을 합쳐 만든 신조어로 회사의 업무를 제대로 수행하지 않고 월급만 받는 직원을 풍자하는 의미로 사용하며 한국의 인터넷 커뮤니티와 직장인들 사이에서 유행
data.Background(English): The term is a portmanteau created by combining the name of the legendary thief 'Arsène Lupin' from the works of French novelist Maurice Leblanc, and 'salary'. It is used sarcastically to refer to employees who do not properly perform their company duties and only collect their salary. This term has become popular among Korean internet communities and office workers.
data.combined_text: 월루 Salary thief (slacker at work) 회사에서 월루하면서 시간을 보내고 있다.

data.Explanation(English): the important thing is an unbent mind
data.Explanation(Korean):
중요한 건 꺾이지 않는 마음
꺾이지 않는 의지 강조
data.Example sentence(Korean): 실패해도 중꺾마 마인드지
data.Background(Korean): 2022 리그 오브 레전드 월드 챔피언십(롤드컵)에서 DRX가 우승한 후, 김혁규(Deft) 선수의 인터뷰 영상 제목인 '중요한 것은 꺾이지 않는 마음'에서 유래함. 해당 문장은 DRX의 극적인 승리를 상징하는 말로 팬들 사이에서 화제가 되었고, 이후 롤드컵 커뮤니티를 중심으로 '중꺾마'라는 유행어로 널리 사용
data.Background(English): The phrase "What's important is an unyielding spirit" is derived from the title of an interview with Kim Hyuk-kyu (Deft) after DRX's victory at the 2022 League of Legends World Championship (LoL World Cup). This phrase, symbolizing DRX's dramatic victory, became a hot topic among fans and subsequently spread widely as a popular term, "Jungkkoekma," within the LoL World Cup community.
data.combined_text: 중꺾마 the important thing is an unbent mind 실패해도 중꺾마 마인드지

data.Background(Korean): 불교 용어 중 악마를 항복시킨다는 의미로 석가모니가 깨달음을 얻기 전 자신을 유혹하는 마라를 물리친 데서 유래한 단어 '항마'에 힘이라는 한자 '력'을 붙여 쓰이는 단어로, 던전앤파이터 등의 인기 게임에서 사용되며 확산
data.Background(English): The term '항마력' is derived from the Buddhist term '항마', which means to subdue the devil, referring to Siddhartha Gautama's defeat of Mara, who tempted him before he attained enlightenment. The Chinese character '력', meaning power, is added to form the word. This term is used and popularized in popular games like Dungeon & Fighter.
data.combined_text: 항마력 power of endurance 이 영상 항마력 테스트다 진짜ㅋㅋㅋ

The term 'President' is replaced with the character '머', which looks similar to '대', the first letter of '대통령' (President), creating a new slang term.

This word reflects the changing perceptions of living arrangements and family structures due to the increase in single-person households and non-marriage trends in Korea.

data.Example sentence(Korean): 아침 공복 유산소부터 한다고? 헬창 인정
data.Background(Korean): 던전앤파이터라는 게임에서 자주 사용되던 단어로, 가장 좋은 등급의 아이템을 얻는 지옥파티를 '헬'에서 플레이하기 위해 PC방에 이른 아침 방문하는 것을 '엠창인생'이라는 비속어를 사용해 언급하는 합성어로서 처음 등장. 이후 의미가 바뀌며 '헬'을 '헬스'의 앞 글자로 의미를 변형하며 사용. 디시 인사이드의 파워리프팅 마이너 갤러리에서 언급되며 일상 속에서 헬스와 관련한 의미로 확산.
data.Background(English): The term first appeared as a compound word in the game Dungeon & Fighter, where it was often used to refer to the act of visiting a PC room early in the morning to play in the 'Hell' party to get the highest-grade items. This act was colloquially referred to as 'M Chang Life'. The meaning later changed, with 'Hell' being altered to the first letter of 'Health', and was used in this transformed context. It was mentioned in the powerlifting minor gallery of DC Inside and spread in everyday life with a meaning related to health.
data.combined_text: 헬창 gym rat, gym bro 아침 공복 유산소부터 한다고? 헬창 인정

data.Background(Korean): 유튜브 '여단오' 채널에서 시작한 신조어로 국제커플의 일화 중 택시 기사님과 대화가 길어졌던 일화를 소개하며 한국어 표현이 어색한 중국인 남자친구가 했던 말이 밈으로 확산. '여단오' 채널의 주 구독자인 2030 여성들이 네이버 블로그 등에서 변형하여 사용.
data.Background(English): The new slang term originated from the YouTube channel 'Yeo Dan Oh'. It was introduced in a story about an international couple who had a lengthy conversation with a taxi driver. The phrase was used by the Chinese boyfriend whose Korean expression was awkward, and it spread as a meme. The main subscribers of the 'Yeo Dan Oh' channel, women in their 20s and 30s, have adapted and used it on platforms like Naver blogs.

data.Explanation(Korean):

음식이면 레시피를 바꾸고, 물건이면 조립/커스텀하는 식. 단순히 사용하는 데 그치지 않고 재조합·재창조해서 더 나은 만족을 추구

data.Explanation(English): Used when something went wrong or failed
data.Background(English): From the verb "valer" (to be worth), this phrase roughly means "It's over" or "We're screwed." Widely used in pop culture, memes, and daily talk. Common across Mexico.
data.combined_text: Ya valió Used when something went wrong or failed ¡Ya valió, ya no hay forma de arreglar esto!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Ya valió, ya no hay forma de arreglar esto!
data.Literal translation: It's already worth it, there's no way to fix this!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It's already over, there's no fixing this!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of failure or bad outcomes.

data.Explanation(English): A warning to be careful or alert
data.Background(English): Originates from the warning "¡Aguas!" shouted in colonial times when people threw dirty water into the street. Evolved into a general warning. Traditional expression.
data.combined_text: Aguas A warning to be careful or alert ¡Aguas! No te acerques a esa zona, está peligrosa.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Aguas! No te acerques a esa zona, está peligrosa.
data.Literal translation: Waters! Don’t get close to that area, it’s dangerous.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Watch out! Stay away from that area, it’s dangerous.
data.Tone: Null

data.Explanation(English): Pretending to listen while ignoring someone
data.Background(English): Comes from the idea of "letting something fly by" without paying attention. Used when someone pretends to listen but ignores you. Often used in casual conversations.
data.combined_text: Me dio el avión Pretending to listen while ignoring someone Me dio el avión cuando me dijo que iba a estudiar todo el día.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me dio el avión cuando me dijo que iba a estudiar todo el día.
data.Literal translation: It gave me the plane when they told me they'd study all day.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I wasn’t listening when they said they’d study all day.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative when someone pretends to listen but doesn't engage.

data.Background(English): Popular in teen slang and media. "Oso" = bear, but slang for shame.
data.combined_text: Qué oso Something embarrassing or cringeworthy ¡Qué oso me dio cuando me di cuenta de que había hablado mal!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué oso me dio cuando me di cuenta de que había hablado mal!
data.Literal translation: What bear gave me when I realized I spoke wrong!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I was so embarrassed when I realized I messed up!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of embarrassment or awkwardness.

data.Background(English): Comes from the use of 20-cent coins in public phones in Mexico. Refers to the moment when a delayed realization or understanding "drops." Idiomatic, rooted in old coin-operated phones.
data.Notes: Idiomatic, rooted in old coin-operated phones
data.combined_text: Me cayó el veinte Realizing or understanding something suddenly ¡Me cayó el veinte de que tengo que estudiar para el examen!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me cayó el veinte de que tengo que estudiar para el examen!
data.Literal translation: The twenty fell on me that I have to study for the exam!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It hit me that I need to study for the exam!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of sudden realization or understanding.

data.Background(English): Fregar means to bother or mess with. This phrase expresses disbelief or reproach. Common in family settings and media. Informal tone.
data.combined_text: Ya ni la friegas Expression of disappointment or reproach Ya ni la friegas, ya sé que me equivoqué.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ya ni la friegas, ya sé que me equivoqué.
data.Literal translation: Don’t even fry it anymore, I know I made a mistake.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Stop, I get it, I messed up.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of frustration or disapproval.

data.Explanation(English): Something is very difficult or intense
data.Background(English): Euphemism for a vulgar Word ("cab***"). Means something is very difficult or intense. Spread through youth culture and media. "Cañón" = strong intensity, mild euphemism.
data.combined_text: Está cañón Something is very difficult or intense ¡Está cañón intentar aprender ese idioma!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Está cañón intentar aprender ese idioma!
data.Literal translation: It's canyon to try to learn that language!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It’s so hard to try to learn that language!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of amazement, but negative in difficulty.

data.Background(English): Agüitado is a regionalism (especially northern Mexico) meaning sad or down. Possibly from "aguado" (watered-down). Spread through music/slang. Common in northern Mexico.
data.combined_text: Ando agüitado Feeling down or sad Ando agüitado porque no me dieron el trabajo.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ando agüitado porque no me dieron el trabajo.
data.Literal translation: I’m all sad because they didn’t give me the job.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m feeling down because I didn’t get the job.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of sadness or disappointment.

data.Background(English): Ironically means "cool" or "awesome". Popularized through youth in Mexico City and TV. "Padre" means "dad" but is used positively here. Positive slang, like "cool".
data.combined_text: Qué padre Expression of joy or excitement ¡Qué padre está este concierto!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué padre está este concierto!
data.Literal translation: How father is this concert!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This concert is so cool!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of excitement or admiration.

data.Background(English): Origin unclear but strongly associated with Mexican youth and counterculture. Means "cool" or "awesome". Spread through media and music. Synonym of "padre", common in central Mexico.
data.Notes: Synonym of "padre", common in central Mexico
data.combined_text: Chido Nice, good, cool Este lugar está bien chido, ¡me encanta!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Este lugar está bien chido, ¡me encanta!
data.Literal translation: This place is very cool, I love it!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This place is awesome, I love it!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of approval or describing something cool.

data.Background(English): From the verb "bajar" (to come down), used to describe a sudden drop in mood or energy. Influenced by youth culture and emotional slang. Influenced by internet culture.
data.combined_text: Me dio el bajón Suddenly feeling down or discouraged Me dio el bajón después de esa mala noticia.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me dio el bajón después de esa mala noticia.
data.Literal translation: It gave me the drop after that bad news.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I felt so down after that bad news.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of emotional or physical downturn.

data.Explanation(English): Used to emphasize honesty or seriousness
data.Background(English): Short for "la neta" meaning "the truth." Popularized in urban youth culture and street language. Means "truth" or "for real?"
data.combined_text: Neta Used to emphasize honesty or seriousness ¡Neta no sé qué hacer con este problema!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Neta no sé qué hacer con este problema!
data.Literal translation: Truth, I don’t know what to do with this problem!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Honestly, I don’t know what to do with this problem!

data.Background(English): From "huevón" (lazy). Expresses boredom or lack of motivation. Widely used by students and in casual settings. Informal, possibly vulgar depending on context.
data.Notes: Informal, possibly vulgar depending on context
data.combined_text: Qué hueva Feeling lazy or bored Qué hueva tener que trabajar un domingo.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Qué hueva tener que trabajar un domingo.
data.Literal translation: What laziness to have to work on a Sunday.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It’s such a drag having to work on a Sunday.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of boredom or unwillingness.

data.Explanation(English): Something is really bad or unpleasant
data.Background(English): Fregada is a euphemism for something harsh or bad. This phrase means something is really bad or messed up. Euphemism for stronger language.
data.combined_text: Está de la fregada Something is really bad or unpleasant Este clima está de la fregada, no aguanto el calor.

data.Literal translation: This weather is from the frying pan, I can’t stand the heat.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This weather sucks, I can’t stand the heat.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of describing something terrible.

data.Explanation(English): Something made you feel weird or uncomfortable
data.Background(English): Used when something gives you discomfort, cringe, or unease. Popular in everyday speech, especially among young people. Used for both physical and emotional discomfort.
data.Notes: Used for both physical and emotional discomfort

data.Literal translation: It gave me a thing when I saw the state of the place.

data.Explanation(English): I like it or I agree
data.Background(English): Latir (to beat, like a heart). Means "I like it" or "I'm into it." Youth slang that spread through pop culture. Casual agreement.

data.Literal translation: It hits me much that idea, let’s do it!

data.Background(English): Vulgar but common. Expresses being fed up. Popular in informal speech and music. Vulgar, very informal.

data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m fed up with all this work, I need a break.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of extreme frustration or exhaustion.

data.Background(English): Onda = vibe. Means feeling confused or shocked. Common among teens and young adults. "Sacado de onda" = thrown off.
data.combined_text: Estoy bien sacado de onda I'm confused or shocked Estoy bien sacado de onda por lo que pasó en la fiesta.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bien sacado de onda por lo que pasó en la fiesta.
data.Literal translation: I’m really thrown off by what happened at the party.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m totally confused by what happened at the party.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of confusion or unease.

data.Explanation(English): No way, not even as a joke
data.Background(English): Means "not even as a joke." Used to strongly reject something. Common in casual speech. Common expression for strong "no".
data.combined_text: Ni de chiste No way, not even as a joke Ni de chiste me voy a subir a esa montaña rusa.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ni de chiste me voy a subir a esa montaña rusa.
data.Literal translation: Not even from a joke, I’m going to get on that roller coaster.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: No way I’m getting on that roller coaster.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of strong disagreement or refusal.

data.Background(English): Expresses resignation or acceptance of a bad situation. Used across generations. Common phrase.
data.combined_text: Ni modo It can't be helped Ni modo, no hay nada que pueda hacer.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ni modo, no hay nada que pueda hacer.
data.Literal translation: No way, there’s nothing I can do.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It can’t be helped, there’s nothing I can do.
data.Tone: Null

data.Explanation(English): Used to dismiss something as irrelevant
data.Background(English): Influenced by texting and Gen Z slang. Used to say something is boring, irrelevant, or indifferent. Popular on social media. Derived from texting culture.
data.combined_text: X Used to dismiss something as irrelevant X, no me importa lo que digan.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): X, no me importa lo que digan.
data.Literal translation: X, I don’t care what they say.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Whatever, I don’t care what they say.

data.Explanation(English): Used to show respect or sadness, like 'paying respects'
data.Background(English): Internet slang from gaming culture ("Press F to pay respects"). Adopted into Spanish to express sympathy or failure. Adopted from gaming/meme culture.
data.combined_text: F Used to show respect or sadness, like 'paying respects' F por lo que pasó!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): F por lo que pasó!
data.Literal translation: F for what happened!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Respect for what happened!
data.Tone: Null

data.Background(English): Euphemism for "no mames." Expresses surprise, disbelief, or annoyance. Used widely in all age groups. Less vulgar version of 'no mames'.
data.combined_text: No manches No way, you're kidding ¡No manches, ¿de verdad?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡No manches, ¿de verdad?
data.Literal translation: Don’t stain, really?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: No way, are you serious?
data.Tone: Null

data.Background(English): Greeting similar to "What's up?" Comes from northern Mexican slang. Spread through music and pop culture. Common in northern Mexico.
data.combined_text: Qué rollo What's up? ¡Qué rollo, ¿cómo has estado?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué rollo, ¿cómo has estado?
data.Literal translation: What roll, how have you been?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What’s up, how have you been?
data.Tone: Null

data.Background(English): Means being broke. Casual way to express financial hardship. Popular among students and young adults. Used humorously.
data.combined_text: Estoy en la ruina I'm broke ¡Estoy en la ruina después de todo lo que gasté en vacaciones!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Estoy en la ruina después de todo lo que gasté en vacaciones!
data.Literal translation: I’m in ruins after everything I spent on vacation!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m broke after all I spent on vacation!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of financial hardship or bad circumstances.

data.Background(English): Exclamation of disappointment, surprise, or disapproval. Origin in urban Mexico City slang, often linked to cholo or barrio culture. Street slang, casual.
data.combined_text: Chale Expression of disappointment or disbelief ¡Chale, ya se me olvidó lo que iba a decir!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Chale, ya se me olvidó lo que iba a decir!
data.Literal translation: Chale, I forgot what I was going to say!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: No way, I totally forgot what I was going to say!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of disappointment or annoyance.

data.Background(English): Chafa = low quality. Used to describe something cheap, disappointing, or fake. Widespread in casual speech. Used to describe poor quality.
data.combined_text: Qué chafa That's low quality or lame ¡Qué chafa que se canceló el evento!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué chafa que se canceló el evento!
data.Literal translation: What lame that the event was canceled!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That sucks that the event got canceled!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of poor quality or dissatisfaction.

data.Background(English): Means someone rubbed you the wrong way. Likely comes from associating "gordo" (fat) with discomfort or annoyance. Spread through casual speech. Literal: 'He/she fell fat on me'.
data.combined_text: Me cayó gordo I don’t like him/her Me cayó gordo lo que hizo mi compañero en clase.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me cayó gordo lo que hizo mi compañero en clase.
data.Literal translation: It fell fat on me what my classmate did.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I really didn’t like what my classmate did in class.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of dislike or annoyance with someone.

data.Background(English): From "panic," Spanglish-style verb. Popularized through urban slang and anxiety-related conversations. Common in stressful situations.
data.combined_text: Estoy bien paniqueado I’m really scared or anxious Estoy bien paniqueado por el examen que tengo mañana.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bien paniqueado por el examen que tengo mañana.
data.Literal translation: I’m really panicked about the exam I have tomorrow.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m freaking out about the exam tomorrow.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of stress or panic.

data.Background(English): Describes something or someone as wild, extreme, or unbelievable. Became widespread in informal speech and media. Context defines if it's positive or negative.
data.Notes: Context defines if it's positive or negative
data.combined_text: Está bien loco That's crazy ¡Está bien loco lo que está pasando en la serie!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Está bien loco lo que está pasando en la serie!
data.Literal translation: It’s really crazy what’s going on in the series!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This is crazy what’s happening in the show!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of amazement, but negative in absurdity.

data.Background(English): Rollo = story/speech/flow. Means you forgot what you were doing or saying. Used often in youth speech. Slang for memory lapse.
data.combined_text: Se me fue el rollo I forgot something Se me fue el rollo cuando me interrumpieron en la charla.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Se me fue el rollo cuando me interrumpieron en la charla.
data.Literal translation: The roll went away when they interrupted me in the talk.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I lost my train of thought when they interrupted me during the talk.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of forgetfulness.

data.Background(English): Short for "me vale madre" — expresses indifference or defiance. Widespread in rebellious or carefree slang. Informal, may be rude depending on tone.
data.Notes: Informal, may be rude depending on tone
data.combined_text: Me vale I don't care Me vale lo que digan los demás, yo voy a hacer lo que quiero.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me vale lo que digan los demás, yo voy a hacer lo que quiero.
data.Literal translation: I don’t care what others say, I’ll do what I want.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I don’t care what anyone says, I’ll do what I want.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of indifference or carelessness.

data.Background(English): Literally "what fart?" but used like "what's going on?" or "what the hell?" Originates from northern Mexico, spread nationwide. Can be greeting or expression of surprise.
data.Notes: Can be greeting or expression of surprise
data.combined_text: Qué pedo What's up / What's the problem? ¡Qué pedo, ¿dónde te habías metido?!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué pedo, ¿dónde te habías metido?!
data.Literal translation: What fart, where had you been?!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What the heck, where have you been?!
data.Tone: Null

data.Background(English): Vulgar, but can mean something is amazing or very good (context dependent). Popular among youth, especially in Mexico City. Vulgar tone, but often used positively.
data.Notes: Vulgar tone, but often used positively
data.combined_text: Está de huevos It's awesome ¡Esa película está de huevos, tienes que verla!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa película está de huevos, tienes que verla!
data.Literal translation: It’s from eggs, you have to see that movie!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This movie is amazing, you have to watch it!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of excitement or approval.

data.Background(English): From "madre" in vulgar expressions. Means chaos or mess. Common in casual and frustrated tones. Vulgar slang.
data.combined_text: Es un desmadre It’s a total mess ¡Es un desmadre todo lo que está pasando con mi proyecto!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Es un desmadre todo lo que está pasando con mi proyecto!
data.Literal translation: It’s a mess everything that’s going on with my project!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It’s a total disaster what’s going on with my project!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in chaotic situations but can be positive in fun contexts.

data.Background(English): From "madre" in vulgar expressions. Means chaos or mess. Originally negative, but also used positively in fun contexts. Vulgar but not offensive in this context.
data.Notes: Vulgar but not offensive in this context.
data.combined_text: Es un desmadre Chaotic but fun  ¡La fiesta de anoche fue un desmadre!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡La fiesta de anoche fue un desmadre!
data.Literal translation: The party last night was a mess!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Last night’s party was wild / a total blast

data.Background(English): Banda refers to your crew. Saying someone "es bien banda" means they're cool, loyal, or down-to-earth. Popular in urban youth culture. Means you're a good part of the crew.
data.Notes: Means you’re a good part of the crew
data.combined_text: Ser bien banda To be humble and nice Él es bien banda, siempre nos ayuda cuando lo necesitamos.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Él es bien banda, siempre nos ayuda cuando lo necesitamos.
data.Literal translation: He is a good band, always helping us when we need him.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: He’s such a good guy, always helping us when we need him.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of loyalty or solidarity within a group.

data.Background(English): Short for "depresión." Casual way to say you're feeling depressed. Common in teen/young adult conversations. Informal abbreviation of 'depresión'.
data.combined_text: Estar en la depre Feeling depressed Estoy en la depre porque no he conseguido trabajo aún.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en la depre porque no he conseguido trabajo aún.
data.Literal translation: I’m in the depression because I haven’t found a job yet.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m feeling down because I still haven’t found a job.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of sadness or depression.

data.Background(English): Means being overwhelmed, full (physically or emotionally), or fed up. Influenced by English and Spanglish use. Casual expression.
data.combined_text: Estar hasta el full To be full / overwhelmed Estoy hasta el full de trabajo, no tengo tiempo para nada.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy hasta el full de trabajo, no tengo tiempo para nada.
data.Literal translation: I’m full to the top with work, I have no time for anything.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m overloaded with work, I have no time for anything.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of being overwhelmed.

data.Background(English): Relaxed way to say "no problem." Often used to reassure or forgive casually. Common among friends. Very informal, possibly vulgar.
data.combined_text: No hay pedo No problem No hay pedo, todo va a estar bien.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): No hay pedo, todo va a estar bien.
data.Literal translation: There’s no fart, everything will be fine.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: No worries, everything’s going to be fine.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of reassurance or lack of concern.

data.Background(English): From "rayarse," slang meaning to get something great or lucky. Often used when receiving an unexpected treat or win. Used when things go unexpectedly well.
data.Notes: Used when things go unexpectedly well
data.combined_text: Me rayé I got lucky / I scored ¡Me invitaron al concierto, me rayé!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me invitaron al concierto, me rayé!
data.Literal translation: They scratched me!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: They invited me to the concert — I totally scored!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of luck or receiving something good.

data.Background(English): Slang for something being really good (like rating it a "1" as best). Not as common, but known in certain regions. Slang, especially in central Mexico.

data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Este lugar está del uno, qué chido!
data.Literal translation: It’s from the one, how cool!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This place is awesome, it’s so cool!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive when describing something really good.

data.Background(English): Perra used to mean bold, fierce, impressive (can be admiring or judgmental depending on tone). Influenced by fashion/media/lgbtq+ slang. Popular among LGBTQ+ communities.
data.combined_text: Qué perra That’s fierce or amazing ¡Qué perra está esa canción, no puedo dejar de escucharla!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué perra está esa canción, no puedo dejar de escucharla!
data.Literal translation: What bitch is that song, I can’t stop listening to it!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This song is fire, I can’t stop listening to it!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in offensive situations but can be positive in slang to describe something impressive.

data.Background(English): From "prender" (to light up). Means being hyped, excited, or turned on (context-dependent). Used in parties or when very enthusiastic. Can be intense energy or emotion.
data.Notes: Can be intense energy or emotion
data.combined_text: Estoy bien prendido I’m excited / pumped Estoy bien prendido por la fiesta que va a haber este fin de semana.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bien prendido por la fiesta que va a haber este fin de semana.
data.Literal translation: I’m really lit for the party that’s going to happen this weekend.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m super excited for the party this weekend.

data.Background(English): Refers to crossing fingers for luck. "Changuitos" = little monkeys. Used playfully, especially among children and women. Common for wishing luck.
data.combined_text: Voy a hacer changuitos I’m crossing my fingers Voy a hacer changuitos para que me salga todo bien en el examen.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Voy a hacer changuitos para que me salga todo bien en el examen.
data.Literal translation: I’m going to make little monkeys for everything to go well in the exam.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m going to cross my fingers so everything goes well in the exam.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of hope or wishing for good luck.

data.Background(English): Means something is luxurious, excellent. Influenced by marketing language, adopted into casual speech. Common across Mexico.
data.combined_text: Está de lujo It’s luxurious or top-notch ¡Está de lujo este lugar, me encanta!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Está de lujo este lugar, me encanta!
data.Literal translation: It’s from luxury, I love this place!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: This place is amazing, I love it!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of admiration or describing something excellent.

data.Background(English): Means to forget something suddenly, like your train of thought. "Avión" = plane; metaphor for zoning out. Informal way to express losing focus.
data.Notes: Informal way to express losing focus
data.combined_text: Se me fue el avión I spaced out ¡Se me fue el avión y no vi la hora, ya me tengo que ir!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Se me fue el avión y no vi la hora, ya me tengo que ir!
data.Literal translation: The plane went away and I didn’t see the time, I have to go now!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I totally lost track of time, I need to go now!
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of forgetfulness or being distracted.

data.Background(English): Clavado = obsessed or deeply into something/someone. Common in love contexts, hobbies, or interests. Romantic or hobby context.
data.combined_text: Ando bien clavado I’m very into something Ando bien clavado viendo esta serie, no puedo parar.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ando bien clavado viendo esta serie, no puedo parar.
data.Literal translation: I’m really stuck watching this series, I can’t stop.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m totally hooked on this series, I can’t stop watching it.

data.Background(English): Used to describe someone as very sweet, kind, or lovable. Common in romantic or affectionate contexts. Common compliment.
data.combined_text: Es un amor He/she is lovely ¡Es un amor mi perrito, siempre me hace compañía!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Es un amor mi perrito, siempre me hace compañía!
data.Literal translation: He/she is a love, my dog always keeps me company!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: My dog is the sweetest, always keeps me company!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive when describing someone kind or lovable.

data.Background(English): Slang for being 100% ready, motivated, or feeling great. Influenced by hip hop and reggaetón culture. Common in northern Mexico.
data.combined_text: Estoy al cien I’m doing great Estoy al cien, ya listo para lo que venga.

data.Literal translation: I’m at a hundred, ready for whatever comes.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m feeling great, ready for whatever comes my way.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of feeling great or being in top condition.

data.Background(English): Means "I can't get anything right." Used in frustrating situations or when feeling useless. Used when things go repeatedly wrong.
data.Notes: Used when things go repeatedly wrong
data.combined_text: No doy una I keep failing ¡No doy una, siempre me equivoco!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡No doy una, siempre me equivoco!
data.Literal translation: I don’t give one, I always make mistakes!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I can’t do anything right, I always mess up!

data.Background(English): Literally "I feel like a rag." Means you feel exhausted, mistreated, or emotionally drained. Common expression of low energy.

data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me siento como trapo después de la carrera.
data.Literal translation: I feel like a rag after the race.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I feel completely exhausted after the race.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of exhaustion or feeling unwell.

data.Background(English): Used to say "meh" or express indifference. Comes from Spanish expressions mimicking disinterest. Common neutral evaluation.
data.combined_text: Ni fu ni fa So-so, not good nor bad La película estuvo ni fu ni fa, no me convenció.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): La película estuvo ni fu ni fa, no me convenció.
data.Literal translation: It was neither fu nor fa, I wasn’t convinced.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: The movie was whatever, it didn’t really convince me.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of indifference or lack of strong feelings.

data.Background(English): Spanglish from "freaked out." Used to express panic or nervousness. Spread via media and youth speech. Borrowed from English, adapted form.
data.combined_text: Estoy bien friqueado I’m freaking out Estoy bien friqueado por la película de terror que vi.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bien friqueado por la película de terror que vi.
data.Literal translation: I’m really freaked out by the horror movie I watched.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m totally freaked out by the horror movie I watched.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of stress, fear, or unease.

data.Background(English): Borrowed from English internet slang "cringe." Adopted into Spanish to describe second-hand embarrassment. Borrowed but fully integrated.

data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me dio cringe cuando vi el video de esa persona!
data.Literal translation: It gave me cringe when I saw that person’s video!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I was so embarrassed when I watched that person’s video!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of second-hand embarrassment or awkwardness.

data.Background(English): Borrowed from English internet slang. Used to describe mistakes or flops. Became popular with meme culture. Borrowed from English, popular online.
data.combined_text: Es un fail It’s a failure ¡Ese examen fue un fail total, no sé qué me pasó!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Ese examen fue un fail total, no sé qué me pasó!
data.Literal translation: It’s a fail, I don’t know what happened!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That exam was a total fail, I don’t know what went wrong!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of failure or mishaps.

data.Background(English): Means something is really cool or awesome. Origin unclear but widespread in informal speech. Older slang, still in use.
