data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa fiesta estuvo de pelos, lo mejor de todo!
data.Literal translation: It’s from hairs, that party was the best!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That party was amazing, the best thing ever!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of admiration or describing something amazing.

data.Background(English): Means "it's not that big a deal." Often used to minimize or calm a situation. Common across generations. Used to downplay a situation.
data.combined_text: No es para tanto It’s not that bad No es para tanto, no te pongas tan dramático.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): No es para tanto, no te pongas tan dramático.
data.Literal translation: It’s not for so much, don’t get so dramatic.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It’s not a big deal, don’t be so dramatic.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of downplaying or minimizing an issue.

data.Background(English): Borrowed from English "in shock." Became popular in the 2000s via media, especially reality shows and dramas. Common emotional response.
data.combined_text: Me quedé en shock I was shocked ¡Me quedé en shock cuando me dijeron que me habían aceptado!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me quedé en shock cuando me dijeron que me habían aceptado!
data.Literal translation: I was in shock when they told me I was accepted!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I was in shock when they told me I got in!
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of surprise or disbelief.

data.Background(English): Diminutive of "ternura" (tenderness). Used sarcastically or genuinely to describe something/someone as sweet or pathetic. Gentle emotional reaction.
data.combined_text: Ternurita It was touching or cute Me dio ternura ver a ese perrito tan chiquito.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me dio ternura ver a ese perrito tan chiquito.
data.Literal translation: It gave me tenderness to see that little dog.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That little dog was so cute, it gave me all the feels.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of affection or describing something cute.

data.Background(English): Spanglish from English "chill." Gained popularity in online culture and among Gen Z. Borrowed but used informally.
data.combined_text: Estoy chill I’m relaxed Estoy chill, no pasa nada, todo está bien.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy chill, no pasa nada, todo está bien.
data.Literal translation: I’m chill, nothing’s going on, everything’s fine.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m totally relaxed, everything’s cool.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of relaxation or feeling calm.

data.Background(English): Expansion of "me dio oso" (I was embarrassed). "Ajeno" = someone else's shame. Influenced by meme culture and social situations. Variant of "qué oso."
data.combined_text: Me dio oso ajeno Secondhand embarrassment ¡Me dio oso ajeno ver ese video viral tan incómodo!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me dio oso ajeno ver ese video viral tan incómodo!
data.Literal translation: It gave me foreign bear to see that awkward viral video!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I felt secondhand embarrassment watching that awkward viral video!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of embarrassment caused by others.

data.Background(English): Spanglish-esque phrase meaning you're in a calm, peaceful, or indifferent state. Popularized by wellness trends and internet language. Borrowed but colloquial.
data.combined_text: Estoy en modo zen I’m super chill Estoy en modo zen, no quiero que nada me estresé hoy.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en modo zen, no quiero que nada me estresé hoy.
data.Literal translation: I’m in zen mode, I don’t want anything stressing me today.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m in zen mode, I don’t want anything to stress me out today.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of peace, relaxation, or calmness.

data.Explanation(English): I put my heart into it
data.Background(English): Means "I put my heart into it." Often used in motivational or romantic contexts. Also influenced by sports/music. Used in effort and passion contexts.
data.Notes: Used in effort and passion contexts
data.combined_text: Le metí corazón I put my heart into it Le metí corazón al proyecto, de verdad me esforcé mucho.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Le metí corazón al proyecto, de verdad me esforcé mucho.
data.Literal translation: I put my heart into the project, I really worked hard on it.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I gave my all to the project, I really put my heart into it.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of effort, passion, or dedication.

data.Background(English): Coraje in Mexican Spanish often means anger or frustration. Common in adult speech to express strong irritation. Often used in frustrating situations.
data.combined_text: Qué coraje Such rage! ¡Qué coraje me da que siempre lleguen tarde!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué coraje me da que siempre lleguen tarde!
data.Literal translation: What anger it gives me that they always arrive late!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What a pain it is that they’re always late!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of frustration, anger, or disappointment.

data.Background(English): Used to describe someone fierce, strong, or brave — especially women or athletes. Literal = wild beast. Compliment for skills.
data.combined_text: Es una fiera He/she is a beast (talented) Es una fiera jugando al fútbol, nadie puede con él.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Es una fiera jugando al fútbol, nadie puede con él.
data.Literal translation: He/she is a beast playing soccer, nobody can handle him/her.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: He’s a beast at soccer, nobody can beat him.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive when describing someone strong, skillful, or fierce.

data.Background(English): Playful misspelling of "ansiedad" (anxiety). A meme term born on social media. Emotion-focused / Misspelling.
data.combined_text: Me dio amsiedad It gave me anxiety ¡Me dio amsiedad ver que no llegaba a tiempo!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me dio amsiedad ver que no llegaba a tiempo!
data.Literal translation: It gave me anxiety to see that I wasn’t arriving on time!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I started freaking out when I saw I was going to be late!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of stress, fear, or unease.

data.Background(English): From cheerleading culture; "porras" = cheers. Means to support or encourage someone verbally. Common in family and friend contexts. Supportive expression.
data.combined_text: Le echo porras I cheer them on Le echo porras a mi amigo para que gane en el torneo.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Le echo porras a mi amigo para que gane en el torneo.
data.Literal translation: I cheer for my friend so he wins in the tournament.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m rooting for my friend to win the tournament.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of encouragement or support.

data.Background(English): From Spanglish "trip" (personal experience/thoughts). Popular in urban slang and among youth; implies being deep in one's thoughts. Personal mood reference.
data.combined_text: Estoy en mi trip I’m in my own world Estoy en mi trip escuchando música todo el día.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en mi trip escuchando música todo el día.
data.Literal translation: I’m in my trip listening to music all day.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m in my own world, just listening to music all day.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of self-focus or introspection.

data.Background(English): Literal: "It broke my soul." Used to express deep sadness or emotional impact. Often used dramatically or sincerely. Used for emotional situations.
data.combined_text: Me partió el alma It broke my heart ¡Me partió el alma ver a mi perro triste!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me partió el alma ver a mi perro triste!
data.Literal translation: It broke my soul to see my dog sad!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: It totally broke my heart to see my dog sad!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of sadness or emotional pain.

data.Background(English): Hermit mode. Internet-influenced slang, especially common post-pandemic. Refers to isolation or anti-social mood. Used humorously.
data.combined_text: Estoy en modo ermitaño I don’t want to socialize Estoy en modo ermitaño, sólo quiero estar en mi casa.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en modo ermitaño, sólo quiero estar en mi casa.
data.Literal translation: I’m in hermit mode, I just want to stay at home.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m in hermit mode, I just want to stay home and avoid everything.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of isolation or solitude.

data.Background(English): Became more casual/common with meme culture; used humorously or seriously to express emotional overwhelm. Humorous exaggeration of stress.
data.combined_text: Estoy en crisis I’m in crisis Estoy en crisis por el montón de tareas que tengo que entregar.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en crisis por el montón de tareas que tengo que entregar.
data.Literal translation: I’m in crisis because of the huge amount of homework I have to turn in.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m totally freaking out because of all the assignments I have to hand in.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of stress, difficulty, or emotional struggle.

data.Background(English): Means "it's disgusting/horrible." Strong informal expression of dislike. Strong negative reaction.
data.combined_text: Está del asco It’s disgusting ¡Esa comida está del asco, no la voy a comer!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa comida está del asco, no la voy a comer!
data.Literal translation: It’s from the disgust, that food is gross, I’m not going to eat it!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That food is disgusting, I’m not eating that!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of disgust or describing something unpleasant.

data.Background(English): Used literally (due to heat) or metaphorically (extreme cuteness or emotion). Common in youth speech. Often used in summer.
data.combined_text: Me estoy derritiendo I’m melting (hot weather) ¡Me estoy derritiendo con este calor!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Me estoy derritiendo con este calor!
data.Literal translation: I’m melting with this heat!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m melting in this heat!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative when describing exhaustion or extreme heat, but positive in situations of expressing love or affection ("me derrito de amor").

data.Background(English): On a tightrope. Refers to being in a risky or unstable situation. Figurative, often used in economic or emotional contexts. Metaphoric expression.
data.combined_text: Estoy en la cuerda floja I’m hanging by a thread Estoy en la cuerda floja con este trabajo, necesito entregarlo pronto.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy en la cuerda floja con este trabajo, necesito entregarlo pronto.
data.Literal translation: I’m on the tightrope with this job, I need to deliver it soon.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m walking a tightrope with this project, I need to turn it in soon.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of uncertainty or risk.

data.Background(English): It filled my heart. Romantic or sentimental phrase often used to express emotional satisfaction. Sentimental tone.
data.combined_text: Me llenó el corazón It filled my heart Ver a mis amigos me llenó el corazón de felicidad.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ver a mis amigos me llenó el corazón de felicidad.
data.Literal translation: Seeing my friends filled my heart.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Seeing my friends made me so happy, I’m full of joy.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of joy, emotional fulfillment, or gratitude.

data.Background(English): Became popular as people talked more openly about mental health and social neglect. Used for emotional vulnerability.
data.combined_text: Me siento invisible I feel invisible Me siento invisible cuando nadie me presta atención.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me siento invisible cuando nadie me presta atención.
data.Literal translation: I feel invisible when nobody pays attention to me.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I feel invisible when no one pays attention to me.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of loneliness or lack of recognition.

data.Background(English): Means "I'm in a bad mood." Widely used across age groups. Simple emotional state.
data.combined_text: Estoy de malas I’m in a bad mood ¡Hoy estoy de malas, todo me molesta!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Hoy estoy de malas, todo me molesta!
data.Literal translation: I’m in a bad mood today, everything bothers me!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m in a bad mood today, everything is annoying me!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of bad mood or annoyance.

data.Background(English): Opposite of "de malas"; means to be in a good mood. Widely used as well. Positive counterpart.
data.combined_text: Estoy de buenas I’m in a good mood ¡Hoy estoy de buenas, todo me sale bien!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Hoy estoy de buenas, todo me sale bien!
data.Literal translation: I’m in a good mood today, everything’s going well!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m in a good mood today, everything is going right!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of good mood or happiness.

data.Background(English): Used when experiencing emotional or physical discomfort that's hard to define. Common in youth speech. Emotionally vague.
data.combined_text: Me siento raro I feel weird Me siento raro con todo este cambio, no sé qué hacer.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me siento raro con todo este cambio, no sé qué hacer.
data.Literal translation: I feel weird with all this change, I don’t know what to do.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I feel weird with all these changes, I don’t know how to handle it.
data.Tone: This Word is considered neutral in situations of confusion or unease.

data.Background(English): Chillar = to cry. Informal, often used when crying out of frustration, sadness, or even laughter. Colloquial for crying.
data.combined_text: Estoy chillando I’m crying ¡Estoy chillando de la emoción por el concierto!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Estoy chillando de la emoción por el concierto!
data.Literal translation: I’m crying from the emotion for the concert!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m literally crying from excitement about the concert!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of crying from emotion or joy, but negative in situations of sadness or frustration.

data.Background(English): Slang for "girl." Commonly used in Mexico and Central America. Used more in Northern and Central Mexico.
data.Notes: Used more in Northern and Central Mexico
data.combined_text: Morra Girl, young woman Esa morra siempre llega tarde.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esa morra siempre llega tarde.
data.Literal translation: That girl always arrives late.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That girl is always late.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral and informal, often used to refer to a girl or young woman.

data.Background(English): Combination of "crush" and the suffix "-azo" to indicate a big crush. Popular among youth. Mix of English "crush" + Spanish "-azo."
data.combined_text: Crushazo Big crush (strong infatuation) Le tengo un crushazo con ese chico.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Le tengo un crushazo con ese chico.
data.Literal translation: I have a crush big with that guy.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I'm really into that guy.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of having a strong crush on someone.

data.Background(English): Pejorative term for someone perceived as pretentious or upper-class, popularized in politics. Used ironically; political connotation.
data.combined_text: Fifi Snobbish or upper-class person Esos chicos fifi no entienden cómo vive la gente común.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esos chicos fifi no entienden cómo vive la gente común.
data.Literal translation: Those kids fifi don't understand how live the people common.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Those rich kids don’t get how regular people live.
data.Tone: This Word is often used negatively to describe someone perceived as upper-class or snobbish.

data.Background(English): From "bajar" (to lower), refers to feeling down or depressed. Common in everyday conversations. From "bajón" + "-eado."
data.combined_text: Bajoneado Feeling emotionally down Estoy bajoneado porque me rechazaron.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bajoneado porque me rechazaron.
data.Literal translation: I'm downed because me rejected.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I'm feeling really low because I got rejected.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative in situations of feeling down or depressed.

data.Explanation(English): A warm hug or comfort gesture
data.Background(English): From Nahuatl "apapachoa," meaning "to embrace" or "to pamper." Widely used for showing affection. From Nahuatl "papachoa"; affectionate Word.
data.combined_text: Apapacho A warm hug or comfort gesture Después de un mal día, mi mamá me dio un apapacho.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Después de un mal día, mi mamá me dio un apapacho.
data.Literal translation: After a bad day, my mom gave me a cuddle.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: After a bad day, my mom comforted me.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive, referring to an affectionate hug or gesture of care.

data.Background(English): From "chamba" (work), means "to work." Common in informal settings and music. Informal; used across Mexico.
data.combined_text: Chambear To work Tengo que chambear el fin de semana.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Tengo que chambear el fin de semana.
data.Literal translation: I have to work the weekend.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I have to work this weekend.
data.Tone: Null

data.Background(English): Expression of disgust. Widely used in Mexican Spanish. Expressive interjection.
data.combined_text: Guácala Gross, disgusting ¡Guácala! Eso huele horrible.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Guácala! Eso huele horrible.
data.Literal translation: Yuck! That smells horrible.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Ugh, that smells terrible.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative, expressing disgust or distaste.

data.Background(English): Slang for "bro" or "dude," often used in urban settings in Mexico. Used in lower-income/urban groups.
data.combined_text: Ñero Close friend or homie Ese es mi ñero, siempre me cuida.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ese es mi ñero, siempre me cuida.
data.Literal translation: That is my ñero, always me cares.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That’s my homie, he always looks out for me.
data.Tone: This Word can be neutral or slightly negative, often used to describe someone rough or from a lower socioeconomic background.

data.Background(English): Means "truth." Often used to emphasize sincerity in conversations. Also used for "truth" or "the real deal."
data.Notes: Also used for "truth" or "the real deal"
data.combined_text: Neta Seriously? For real? ¿Neta vas a venir a la fiesta?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¿Neta vas a venir a la fiesta?
data.Literal translation: Really you going to come to the party?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Are you really going to come to the party?
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, used to express truth or sincerity, akin to "really" or "seriously."

data.Background(English): Refers to a style of dance associated with reggaeton music. Popular in Latin clubs. Related to urban music culture.
data.combined_text: Perreo Sensual dancing (reggaetón) ¡Vamos a bailar perreo toda la noche!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Vamos a bailar perreo toda la noche!
data.Literal translation: Let's dance perreo all the night!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Lets dance reggaeton all night long!
data.Tone: This Word is neutral to positive, referring to a style of dance associated with reggaeton music.

data.Background(English): Slang for "guy" or "dude." Common in Mexican Spanish. Northern Mexican slang.
data.combined_text: Bato Guy, dude Ese bato es muy tranquilo.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ese bato es muy tranquilo.
data.Literal translation: That guy is very calm.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That guy is super chill.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, used informally to refer to a guy or dude.

data.Background(English): Means "let's go" or "let's do it." Used to express readiness or agreement. Interjection; often shouted.
data.combined_text: Sobres Let’s go! (encouragement) ¡Sobres, vamos a la playa!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Sobres, vamos a la playa!
data.Literal translation: Let's go, let's go to the beach!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Let’s hit the beach!
data.Tone: This Word is neutral to positive, used to express agreement or readiness.

data.Background(English): Originates from Mexican Spanish, meaning "cool" or "nice." Became popular in pop culture and music. Used across Mexico; informal slang.
data.combined_text: Chido Cool, nice, good ¡Esa fiesta estuvo bien chida!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa fiesta estuvo bien chida!
data.Literal translation: That party was very cool!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That party was awesome!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive in situations of approval or describing something cool.

data.Background(English): From "trip," meaning to be confused or in a strange mood. Used in youth slang. From "trip" in English + Spanish suffix.
data.combined_text: Tripiado Feeling strange/weird or high Me siento bien tripiado, no sé qué hacer.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Me siento bien tripiado, no sé qué hacer.
data.Literal translation: I feel well tripped, don't know what to do.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I feel really weird, I don’t know what to do.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, used to describe being confused or deep in thought.

data.Background(English): Large party or getting very drunk. Common in Mexican youth culture. From "pedo" + augmentative "-ón."
data.combined_text: Pedón Big drinking session El viernes me voy a echar un buen pedón.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): El viernes me voy a echar un buen pedón.
data.Literal translation: On Friday I’m going to have a good drinking.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m going to have a crazy drinking session on Friday.
data.Tone: This Word is negative, referring to a big party or getting very drunk.

data.Background(English): Expression of disappointment or resignation. Widely used in everyday conversation. Interjection, common in Mexico City.
data.combined_text: Chale Oh no! Damn! ¡Chale, no me digas eso!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Chale, no me digas eso!
data.Literal translation: Oh no, don't me say that!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Damn, don’t say that to me!
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative, expressing disappointment or dismay.

data.Background(English): Pejorative term for someone perceived as snobby or upper-class. Common in Mexican slang. Class-related stereotype.
data.combined_text: Fresa Snobby or preppy person Esos chicos son bien fresas, no entienden nada.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esos chicos son bien fresas, no entienden nada.
data.Literal translation: Those guys are very fresh, don't understand anything.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Those kids are so preppy, they don’t get it.
data.Tone: This Word is often negative, describing someone perceived as snobbish or preppy.

data.Background(English): Pejorative term for someone perceived as vulgar or lower-class. Common in Mexican slang. Controversial; classist term.
data.combined_text: Naco Tacky or low-class No quiero estar cerca de esa gente naca.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): No quiero estar cerca de esa gente naca.
data.Literal translation: I don't want to be near that low-class people.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I don’t want to be near those tacky people.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative, used to describe someone perceived as tacky or lacking sophistication.

data.Background(English): From "brother," used to refer to a close friend. Common in youth slang. From English "brother" + Spanishized.
data.combined_text: Broder Friend, buddy ¿Qué onda, broder?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¿Qué onda, broder?
data.Literal translation: What's up, broder?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What's up, dude?
data.Tone: This Word is neutral to positive, used informally to refer to a friend or buddy.

data.Background(English): Slang for "woman" or "girlfriend." Common in informal contexts. Low-register; urban slang.
data.combined_text: Vieja Girl, girlfriend (slang) Esa vieja es súper divertida.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esa vieja es súper divertida.
data.Literal translation: That old is super funny.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That girl is really fun.
data.Tone: This Word can be neutral to slightly negative, used informally to refer to a woman or girlfriend.

data.Background(English): Refers to something bad or unpleasant. Common in Mexican Spanish. Also means "ugly" or "harsh."
data.combined_text: Gacho Bad, mean, unfair El clima hoy está bien gacho.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): El clima hoy está bien gacho.
data.Literal translation: The weather today is very bad.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: The weather is terrible today.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative, used to describe something mean or unpleasant.

data.Background(English): Means "awesome" or "badass." Widely used in Mexican Spanish. Strong, informal; masculine-coded.
data.combined_text: Chingón Awesome, badass ¡Eso estuvo bien chingón!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Eso estuvo bien chingón!
data.Literal translation: That was very badass!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That was so badass!
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive, used to describe something impressive or excellent.

data.Background(English): Means "chat" or "hangout." Common in informal conversations. Used for informal gatherings.
data.combined_text: Cotorreo Hangout, fun time Nos vamos a echar un buen cotorreo este fin de semana.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Nos vamos a echar un buen cotorreo este fin de semana.
data.Literal translation: We are going to have a good hangout this weekend.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: We’re going to have a blast this weekend.
data.Tone: This Word is considered positive, referring to chatting or having a good time socially.

data.Background(English): Means "to share" or "to pass around," often used with music or substances. Common in music/slang culture.
data.combined_text: Rolar To share or pass (e.g. music) ¿Me rolas la canción que estás escuchando?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¿Me rolas la canción que estás escuchando?
data.Literal translation: Can you roll me the song that you are listening?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Can you send me the song you’re listening to?
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, meaning to share or pass around, often used in social contexts.

data.Background(English): Means "broken" or "burnt out." Used in various contexts. From "tronar" (to burst/break).
data.combined_text: Tronado Broken up or fired Estoy bien tronado, necesito descansar.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy bien tronado, necesito descansar.
data.Literal translation: I am very broken, I need to rest.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m exhausted, I need to take a break.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative, used to describe being broken, either physically or emotionally.

data.Background(English): Popularized by music, refers to style or flavor. Afro-Caribbean origin; popularized by music.
data.combined_text: Saoko Style, flavor, flow ¡Esa canción tiene mucho saoko!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa canción tiene mucho saoko!
data.Literal translation: That song has a lot of saoko!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That song has so much flow!
data.Tone: This Word is generally positive, often used to express energy, rhythm, or excitement, popularized by music.

data.Background(English): Slang for "work" or "job." Common in informal contexts. Standard slang.
data.combined_text: Chamba Job Estoy buscando chamba.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estoy buscando chamba.
data.Literal translation: I am looking for work.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I’m job hunting.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, meaning work or job.

data.Background(English): Means "yes" or "of course." Informal agreement in Mexican Spanish. Mexicanized form of "sí."
data.combined_text: Simón Yes (slang) Simón, voy para allá.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Simón, voy para allá.
data.Literal translation: Simon, I am going there.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Yeah, I’m on my way.
data.Tone: This Word is positive, used to express agreement, similar to saying "yes" or "sure."

data.Background(English): Refers to excessive or absurd behavior. Popular in internet culture. From "mamar"; often used online.
data.combined_text: Mame Hype, obsession, trend ¡Qué mame, ya no puedo con esto!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué mame, ya no puedo con esto!
data.Literal translation: What hype, I can't with this!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What a trend, I can’t handle this anymore!
data.Tone: This Word is neutral to negative, often used to describe a trend or hype that's exaggerated.

data.Background(English): Combination of "bato" (guy) and "loco" (crazy), used in urban slang. Compound of "bato" + "loco."
data.combined_text: Bato-loco Crazy dude ¡Ese bato-loco está haciendo locuras!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Ese bato-loco está haciendo locuras!
data.Literal translation: That crazy guy is doing craziness!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That dude is acting wild!
data.Tone: This Word can be positive or neutral, describing a guy acting wild or crazy.

data.Background(English): Refers to something useless or troublesome. Common in Mexican Spanish. Offensive but versatile.
data.combined_text: Chingadera Thingy, crap ¿Quién dejó esta chingadera aquí?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¿Quién dejó esta chingadera aquí?
data.Literal translation: Who left this crap here?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Who left this thing here?
data.Tone: This Word is negative, often used to describe something as junk or a nuisance.

data.Background(English): Means "burn" or "embarrassment." Used in informal settings. From "quemar" + augmentative.
data.combined_text: Quemon Embarrassing moment Qué quemon, me acabo de caer frente a todos.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Qué quemon, me acabo de caer frente a todos.
data.Literal translation: What shame, I just fell in front of all.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What a shame, I just got exposed in front of everyone.
data.Tone: This Word is negative, referring to a burn or embarrassing moment.

data.Background(English): Refers to someone who backs out or is cowardly. Used in casual talk. From "sacar" + augmentative.
data.combined_text: Sacón Scaredy-cat ¡Eres un sacón!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Eres un sacón!
data.Literal translation: You are a scaredy-cat!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: You’re such a coward!
data.Tone: This Word is negative, used to describe someone who backs out or is cowardly.

data.Background(English): Variation of "amigo" (friend), popular in social media. Mix of "amiga/o" + cutesy spelling.
data.combined_text: Amix Bestie, friend Te quiero mucho, amix.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Te quiero mucho, amix.
data.Literal translation: I love you a lot, amix.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I love you so much, my bestie.
data.Tone: This Word is positive, an affectionate term for a friend, similar to "friend" or "buddy."

data.Background(English): Shortened from "mirando," meaning "watching." Used in casual talk. From "mirando" pronounced lazily.
data.combined_text: Milando Looking, watching No dejes de milando a esa chica.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): No dejes de milando a esa chica.
data.Literal translation: Don’t stop looking at that girl.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Stop staring at that girl.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, often used in informal contexts, meaning looking or observing.

data.Background(English): Playful variation of "chido," emphasizing coolness. Used in youth slang. Hybrid playful formation.
data.combined_text: Chido-one Coolest one ¡Eres el chido-one de este grupo!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Eres el chido-one de este grupo!
data.Literal translation: You are the cool-one of this group!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: You’re the coolest in the group!
data.Tone: This Word is positive, a playful alteration of "chido," meaning something really cool or awesome.

data.Background(English): Popularized by reggaeton music, refers to a powerful or confident woman. Popularized by reggaetón.
data.combined_text: Bichota Powerful woman, boss ¡Esa mujer es una bichota!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa mujer es una bichota!
data.Literal translation: That woman is a big boss!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That woman is a powerhouse!
data.Tone: This Word is positive, used to describe a strong, independent, and confident woman, popularized by music.

data.Background(English): Slang for "house" or "home." Common in urban areas. Urban youth term.
data.combined_text: Jato House (urban slang) Vamos a mi jato después de la fiesta.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Vamos a mi jato después de la fiesta.
data.Literal translation: Let's go to my house after the party.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Let’s go to my place after the party.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral and informal, often used to refer to a house or home.

data.Background(English): Refers to showing off style or confidence. Popular in music culture. Popular in music/fashion circles.
data.combined_text: Tirando flow Showcasing style Estás tirando flow con ese look.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estás tirando flow con ese look.
data.Literal translation: You are throwing flow with that look.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: You’re rocking that look.
data.Tone: This Word is positive, used to describe someone who is stylish or has a good vibe.

data.Background(English): Short for "vibrations," used to describe atmosphere or feelings. Part of spiritual/wellness lingo.
data.combined_text: Vibras Vibes, mood ¿Qué vibras traes hoy?
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¿Qué vibras traes hoy?
data.Literal translation: What vibes are you bringing today?
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: What’s your vibe today?
data.Tone: This Word is positive, often used to refer to good or bad vibes/energy.

data.Background(English): Used to describe a harmful or toxic person, especially in relationships. Social media slang.
data.combined_text: Tóxico Toxic partner or behavior Estaba en una relación tóxica.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estaba en una relación tóxica.
data.Literal translation: I was in a toxic relation.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I was in a toxic relationship.
data.Tone: This Word is negative, used to describe someone or something harmful or unhealthy, often in relationships.

data.Background(English): Refers to lifestyle or the way one conducts themselves. From "andar"; poetic feel.
data.combined_text: Andares Way of being, vibe Tienes unos andares muy tranquilos.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Tienes unos andares muy tranquilos.
data.Literal translation: You have some way of walking very calm.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: You have a really chill vibe.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, referring to the way someone walks or their demeanor.

data.Background(English): Means "whiny" or "crybaby." Used in informal conversations. From "chillar" + suffix.
data.combined_text: Chillón Crybaby or whiner No seas chillón, ya no llorés.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): No seas chillón, ya no llorés.
data.Literal translation: Don’t be a crybaby, stop crying.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Stop being such a crybaby, it’s fine.
data.Tone: This Word is negative, used to describe someone who cries or complains a lot.

data.Background(English): Refers to a person who drinks a lot or is often drunk. From "pedo" + augmentative.
data.combined_text: Pedote Heavy drinker ¡Esa fiesta fue un pedote!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Esa fiesta fue un pedote!
data.Literal translation: That party was a big drinking!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That party was insane!
data.Tone: This Word is negative, referring to a big problem or a person who drinks excessively.

data.Background(English): Embarrassment or being exposed. Common in youth slang. From "quemar" + noun suffix.
data.combined_text: Quemón Sudden shame or exposure ¡Qué quemón, me acaban de exponer en las redes!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Qué quemón, me acaban de exponer en las redes!
data.Literal translation: What burn, I just exposed in the networks!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I can’t believe I just got exposed online!
data.Tone: This Word is negative, indicating embarrassment or when someone is caught in an awkward situation.

data.Background(English): Refers to overindulgence, often with substances. From "pasarse."
data.combined_text: Pasón Overdose or too much ¡Ayer me di un pasón!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Ayer me di un pasón!
data.Literal translation: That video was of passion!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That video was way too much!
data.Tone: This Word is negative, often referring to an overdose or excess of something, typically drugs or partying.

data.Background(English): Means "outing" or "going out." Used in casual contexts. Used emotionally.
data.combined_text: Salida Fix, escape, solution Encontré la salida de este problema.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Encontré la salida de este problema.
data.Literal translation: I found the exit of this problem.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I found the solution to this issue.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, referring to an outing or a way out of a situation.

data.Background(English): Refers to being stuck or in a difficult situation. From "perro" metaphor.
data.combined_text: Aperrado Obsessed, intense Está bien aperrado con ese proyecto.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Está bien aperrado con ese proyecto.
data.Literal translation: He is very scared with that project.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: He’s super obsessed with that project.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral to negative, used to describe someone who is stubborn or persistent, akin to "clinging like a dog."

data.Background(English): Means "really crazy." Used to describe wild behavior or situations. Colloquial exaggeration.
data.combined_text: Bien loco Super crazy Estás bien loco si piensas hacer eso.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Estás bien loco si piensas hacer eso.
data.Literal translation: You are very crazy if you think to do that.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: You’re out of your mind if you do that.
data.Tone: This Word can be positive or negative, used to describe someone acting wild or crazy.

data.Background(English): Refers to being very intoxicated, often from drugs. Mixed with English.
data.combined_text: Andar bien high Being very high ¡Estoy bien high!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Estoy bien high!
data.Literal translation: I’m very high!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I'm so high right now!
data.Tone: This Word is negative, referring to being very intoxicated, typically from drugs.

data.Background(English): From Venezuelan slang, means "friends." Popularized through social media and Latin music. Common in Latin America, adopted in Mexico.
data.Notes: Common in Latin America, adopted in Mexico
data.combined_text: Panas Friends, close buddies Esos son mis panas, siempre me apoyan.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esos son mis panas, siempre me apoyan.
data.Literal translation: Those are my friends, always me support.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Those are my buddies, they always have my back.
data.Tone: This Word is positive, used to refer to friends or buddies, similar to "mates."

data.Background(English): Refers to something overly sentimental or cheesy. Common in Spanish-speaking countries. Used mockingly or with affection.
data.combined_text: Cursi Cheesy, overly romantic Esa película estuvo bien cursi
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esa película estuvo bien cursi
data.Literal translation: That movie was very cheesy, made me shame.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That movie was so cheesy, it was embarrassing.
data.Tone: This Word can be neutral to negative, describing something as overly sentimental or cheesy.

data.Background(English): Slang for a very attractive man. Often used in informal conversations. From "papá" + augmentative.
data.combined_text: Papucho Hot guy, handsome ¡Ese tipo está bien papucho!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡Ese tipo está bien papucho!
data.Literal translation: That guy is very handsome!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That guy is so hot!
data.Tone: This Word is positive, often used to describe a handsome or attractive man.

data.Background(English): Means "laid-back" or "lazy." Used in various Spanish-speaking regions. From "tirar," meaning "thrown."
data.combined_text: Tirado Exhausted or wasted Después de la fiesta, todos se fueron tirados a dormir.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Después de la fiesta, todos se fueron tirados a dormir.
data.Literal translation: After the party, everyone left thrown to sleep.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: After the party, everyone just crashed and went to sleep.
data.Tone: This Word is neutral, meaning to be lying down or can be negative, implying being lazy.

data.Background(English): Literally "shit of laughter," means something extremely funny. Common in informal settings. Crude; common in informal groups.
data.combined_text: Cague de risa Hilarious, laughing hard Esa broma me dio un cague de risa.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Esa broma me dio un cague de risa.
data.Literal translation: That joke gave me a big laugh.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I died laughing at that joke.
data.Tone: This Word is positive, referring to something extremely funny.

data.Background(English): Refers to being deflated or discouraged. Common in Latin American slang. Baseball metaphor; "ponche."
data.combined_text: Ponchado Exhausted, worn out El carro está ponchado, no podemos ir.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): El carro está ponchado, no podemos ir.
data.Literal translation: The car is punctured, we can't go.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: The car has a flat tire, we can’t go.
data.Tone: This Word is negative, often used to describe someone who is tired or deflated, literally or metaphorically.

data.Background(English): Refers to someone nerdy or overly studious. Common in Mexican Spanish. Used lovingly or critically.

data.Example sentence(Spanish): No seas tan ñoño, ¡anímate a salir!
data.Literal translation: Don't be so nerdy, cheer up to go out!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: Stop being so nerdy, let’s go out!

data.Background(English): Means feeling down or discouraged. Common in Mexican slang. From Nahuatl roots.

data.Example sentence(Spanish): Después de la pelea, estaba todo achicopalado.
data.Literal translation: After the fight, he was all down.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: He was really down after the fight.

data.Background(English): Means "gassy" or refers to something of poor quality. Used humorously. From "pedo," used insultingly.

data.Literal translation: That movie was very stinky.

data.Background(English): From "hardcore," used to describe someone tough or intense. Popular in youth culture. Spanglish pronunciation of "hardcore."

data.Background(English): Refers to someone who is swinging between moods or activities. From "swing"; music slang.

data.Background(English): Slang for "lazy person." Widely used in Latin America. Also used affectionately among friends.

data.Background(English): Combination of "vato" (guy) and "loco" (crazy), used in urban slang. Street culture term.

data.Background(English): Means "super cool" or "very nice." Used to describe positive people or situations. Exaggeration using "onda."

data.Background(English): Refers to someone annoying or pretentious. Common in Mexican Spanish. Can be playful or insulting.

data.Background(English): Means "conceited" or "show-off." Used in informal conversations. Used in family and friend contexts.

data.Background(English): Means "ridiculous" or "absurd." Used in everyday language. Common for joking.

data.Background(English): Refers to being deeply infatuated with someone. Used humorously or seriously. Crude, from "culo," very informal.

data.Background(English): Phonetic adaptation of "love you," popular in text and social media among youth. Used in texting.

data.Background(English): From "cute," refers to someone deemed adorable. Used in informal settings. From English "cute."

data.Background(English): Means "heartbreaker." Used to describe someone who attracts and hurts others romantically. Common in reggaetón.

data.Background(English): Means "awesome" or "cool." Popular in youth slang and music. Adapted from English "flame."

data.Background(English): Intensified form of "perro" (dog), means "extremely cool" or "awesome." From "perro," exaggerated positive slang.

data.Background(English): Means "overwhelmed" or "sick of something sweet." Used metaphorically and literally. Literal and metaphorical use.

data.Background(English): Slang for a light slap or playful hit on the head. Used humorously. Used among siblings or friends.

data.Background(English): Means "so-and-so" or "someone," used to refer to an unspecified person. Generic placeholder name.

data.Background(English): Refers to someone who is overly dramatic. Used in casual conversations. Used in theater or emotional contexts.

data.Background(English): Means "broke" or "bankrupt." Used in informal settings. Also used for financial problems.

data.Background(English): Diminutive of "broder," meaning "little brother" or close friend. Diminutive, affectionate form of "broder."

data.Explanation(English): To steal someone’s crush or partner
data.Background(English): From "chapulín" (grasshopper), means to date a friend's ex. Popular in social media. From "chapulín" (grasshopper).

data.Literal translation: I don’t like to jump in the relationship, but she did it.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I don’t like to be a homewrecker, but she did it.

data.Background(English): Diminutive of "eyes," used as a term of endearment. Used in compliments or teasing.

data.Background(English): Slang for "girl" or "young woman." Common in Mexican Spanish. Used in Central and Southern Mexico.

data.Background(English): Means "unlucky" or "jinxed." Common in various Spanish-speaking regions. Common in superstitions or jokes.

data.Background(English): Refers to being "burned out" or "exposed." Used in informal settings. From "quemar."

data.Background(English): Means "relaxed" or "easy-going." Borrowed from English, popular in youth slang. From English, used as-is.

data.Background(English): Means "annoying" or "irritating." Common in everyday language. Common in polite complaints.

data.Background(English): From English "cancel," refers to rejecting or dismissing someone/something. Popular in media. Newer, social-media use.

data.Background(English): Diminutive of "flojera," meaning "laziness." Used casually. Diminutive of "flojera."

data.Background(English): Means "sharp" or "smart," sometimes used ironically. Mexican slang for talented people.

data.Background(English): Diminutive of "sueño," meaning "nap" or "little sleep." Used in casual contexts. Diminutive of "sueño."

data.Background(English): From "roast," referring to making fun of someone. Adopted from English slang. From English "roast."

data.Background(English): Augmented form of "sorpresa," meaning "big surprise." Used humorously or emphatically. From "sorpresa" + augmentative.

data.Background(English): Means "an amazing person." Common in casual compliments. Tone changes meaning.

data.Explanation(English): Used when someone went all-in or took things too far

data.Explanation(English): Used to describe someone or something powerful or striking

data.Explanation(English): Used to describe someone who looks stylish, attractive, or well-dressed
data.Background(English): Slang for someone stylish or fashionable. Popularized in Latin American youth slang. Originally from Argentina, now used in other Spanish-speaking countries through social media.

data.Explanation(English): Used humorously to say something is emotionally overwhelming
data.Background(English): Means "I can't handle it anymore." Popular in social media and memes. Viral slang on TikTok and social media. Tone depends on context — often playful, ironic, or dramatic.
data.Notes: Viral slang on TikTok and social media. Tone depends on context — often playful, ironic, or dramatic.
data.combined_text: No estoy soportando Used humorously to say something is emotionally overwhelming ¡No estoy soportando lo hermosa que está esta canción!
data.Example sentence(Spanish): ¡No estoy soportando lo hermosa que está esta canción!
data.Literal translation: I’m not supporting how beautiful this song is!
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: I literally can’t handle how beautiful this song is!

data.Explanation(English): A slang term used to describe someone who has been "canceled" or criticized heavily on social media.
data.Background(English): Refers to being "canceled" or criticized publicly. Popular in internet culture. Derived from "funar" (to accuse or expose someone publicly).
data.Notes: Derived from "funar" (to accuse or expose someone publicly).
data.combined_text: Funado A slang term used to describe someone who has been "canceled" or criticized heavily on social media. Ese influencer fue funado por sus comentarios polémicos.
data.Example sentence(Spanish): Ese influencer fue funado por sus comentarios polémicos.
data.Literal translation: That influencer was canceled for their controversial comments.
data.Natural translation (adapted to the cont: That influencer was exposed and heavily criticized.
data.Tone: This Word is considered negative when referring to social rejection or cancellation.
